intro: Calyptrogyne occidentalis, commonly known as the West Indian mangrove, is a flowering plant native to the Caribbean and parts of Central America. It is a member of the family Myrtaceae and is characterized by its ability to thrive in brackish water environments. The plant has small, fragrant white flowers that are typically clustered in inflorescences. Its leaves are opposite and elliptic, often with a waxy coating to reduce water loss. Calyptrogyne occidentalis plays an important ecological role in coastal ecosystems, providing habitat for various marine and terrestrial species.
